div.head: Observer-Based Piecewise Affine Output Feedback Controller Synthesis of Continuous-Time T-S Fuzzy
div.p: Affine Dynamic Systems Using Quantized Measurements Jianbin Qiu, Member, IEEE, Gang Feng, Fellow, IEEE, and Huijun Gao, Senior Member, IEEE

Abstract-This paper is concerned with the problem of robust H ∞ output feedback control for a class of continuoustime Takagi-Sugeno (T-S) fuzzy affine dynamic systems using quantized measurements. The objective is to design a suitable observer-based dynamic output feedback controller that guarantees the global stability of the resulting closed-loop fuzzy system with a prescribed H ∞ disturbance attenuation level. Based on common/piecewise quadratic Lyapunov functions combined with S-procedure and some matrix inequality convexification techniques, some new results are developed to the controller synthesis for the underlying continuous-time T-S fuzzy affine systems with unmeasurable premise variables. All the solutions to the problem are formulated in the form of linear matrix inequalities (LMIs). Finally, two simulation examples are provided to illustrate the advantages of the proposed approaches.
Index Terms-Controller design, measurement quantization, piecewise Lyapunov functions, robust H ∞ control, Takagi-Sugeno (T-S) fuzzy affine dynamic systems.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: F UZZY systems and control have attracted a great deal of attention from both the academic and industrial communities during the past few decades. Tremendous effort has been devoted to both theoretical research and implementation techniques for fuzzy controllers [1]- [3]. It has been well recognized that fuzzy control is a simple and effective approach to controlling many complex nonlinear systems or even nonanalytic systems [1]- [5]. In many cases, fuzzy logic control (FLC) has been suggested as an alternative approach to conventional control techniques. However, it is also worth mentioning that the traditional FLC techniques suffer from a number of disadvantages such as the difficulty for systematic design and inconsistent performance. Recent research efforts have led to numerous results on systematic stability analysis and controller synthesis of continuous-and discrete-time fuzzy control systems [2]- [5], where the Takagi-Sugeno (T-S) fuzzy models or the so-called fuzzy dynamic models are used. See [2] and [3] and survey papers [6] and [7], and references cited therein, for the most recent advances on this topic.

The key idea of T-S fuzzy models is to use a set of fuzzy rules to describe a global nonlinear system in terms of a set of local linear models, which are smoothly connected by fuzzy membership functions. The appeal of T-S fuzzy models is that they combine the flexible fuzzy logic theory and fruitful linear multivariable system theory into a unified framework so that the control design and analysis can be carried out via Lyapunov function-based approaches. The earlier approaches often employ common quadratic Lyapunov functions (CQLFs). It has been shown that the stability and stabilization of the overall fuzzy system can be determined by solving a set of linear matrix inequalities with a common positive-definite Lyapunov matrix [4], [8]- [14]. Nevertheless, a CQLF might not exist for many fuzzy systems, especially for highly nonlinear complex systems. In fact, it has been shown that there are many fuzzy systems that do not admit such a CQLF, whereas they may still be asymptotically stable [3], [6], [7]. This has motivated the development of more advanced approaches such as the piecewise/fuzzy(nonquadratic) Lyapunov function-based approaches. To mention a few, in [5] and [15], a number of results on analysis and synthesis approaches that are based on piecewise Lyapunov functions are presented. However, due to the discontinuity of the function across the region boundaries, for these methods based on the piecewise Lyapunov function, certain restrictive boundary conditions have to be imposed to ensure the stability of the system. More recently, in [16], a different kind of piecewise Lyapunov function has been introduced, and a stability result for continuous-time fuzzy dynamic systems that are based on this piecewise Lyapunov function, which is continuous across region boundaries of the state space [16], [17] has been developed. In [18]- [24], a number of stability analysis, robust stabilization, and filtering design results for discrete-time fuzzy dynamic systems that are based on pieecewise/fuzzy(nonquadratic) Lyapunov functions have been developed. It was also demonstrated in these works that the piecewise/fuzzy Lyapunov functions are a much richer class of Lyapunov function candidates than the CQLF candidates and, thus, is able to handle a larger class of fuzzy dynamic systems.

On the other hand, networked control systems (NCSs) have attracted great attention in control community due to their successful applications in a broad range of areas such as transportation networks, power grids, mobile sensor networks, water distribution networks, haptics collaboration over the Internet, unmanned aerial vehicles, and so on [25], [26]. Nevertheless, the utilization of networks as a communication medium in feedback loops brings us new challenges, which makes the analysis and synthesis of control systems much more complex and difficult due to their limited transmission capacity. Among a number of issues that arise from such a framework, the quantization effect is an important issue to be addressed. In a network environment, signals are usually quantized before being communicated, and the number of quantization levels is closely related to the information flow between the system components and, thus, to the capacity that is required to transmit the information [27], [28].

More recently, there have been some results on robust controller/filter analysis and synthesis for network-based fuzzy dynamic systems in the open literature; see, for example, [29]- [39]. To mention a few, in [29]- [31], some results on robust stabilization and H ∞ control for a class of discrete-time T-S fuzzy systems with packet dropout based on common/fuzzy-basisdependent Lyapunov functions have been presented. In [32], some results on robust H ∞ dynamic output feedback control of discrete-time T-S fuzzy systems with packet dropout and time delay based on a CQLF have been presented. We have also proposed some new results on output feedback control and robust filtering design of discrete-time networked T-S fuzzy dynamic systems that are based on piecewise Lyapunov functions [33]- [36]. In the continuous-time context, the authors in [37]- [39] studied the guaranteed cost control and robust H ∞ control for a class of networked T-S fuzzy systems with packet dropout and/or time delay based on a common Lyapunov function/functional. It is noted that due to the particular structure of piecewise Lyapunov matrices and decoupling techniques for corresponding stability/performance analysis conditions, the controller synthesis for continuous-time networked (or non-networked) T-S fuzzy affine systems that are based on piecewise quadratic Lyapunov functions (PQLFs) are more difficult and challenging than that for the discrete-time case [16], [17], [33], [34].

Nevertheless, there are, to the authors' best knowledge, very few results that are available in the literature on the output feedback controller design for continuous-time networked (or non-networked) T-S fuzzy affine (or non-affine) systems based on the PQLFs, especially when the plant premise variables are not measurable. Note that the output feedback control is particularly very useful and more realistic owing to the partially measurable state variables in practical applications. Recently, some results on the design of observer-based output feedback control for continuous-time fuzzy systems without affine terms have been reported in the literature [8], [10]- [12], [14], which are mainly based on CQLFs and, thus, tend to be conservative. This motivates us to adopt PQLFs in output feedback controller synthesis which shall make the resulting controller less conservative and more applicable in practice though the computation cost of the controller design with PQLFs is more demanding.

In this paper, we will consider the observer-based robust H ∞ output feedback control for a class of networked nonlinear systems using quantized measurements. Specifically, the nonlinear system is represented by a continuous-time T-S fuzzy affine dynamic model with norm-bounded parametric uncertainties, and the quantization error is treated using a sector bound method [28]. It is also assumed that the plant premise variables are not measurable; therefore, there is no guarantee that the plant and the controller always operate in the same region at the same time, i.e., they may not synchronize in transition from one region to another. Based on common/PQLFs combined with S-procedure and some matrix inequality convexification techniques, three new synthesis approaches will be proposed. The first design approach is based on a CQLF, while the other two are based on PQLFs. It will be shown that the resulting closedloop fuzzy system is globally stable with a guaranteed H ∞ performance, and the observer/controller gains can be obtained by solving a set of linear matrix inequalities.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. Section II formulates the problem under consideration. Section III presents three approaches to controller synthesis based on common and PQLFs, respectively. Two simulation examples are presented to demonstrate the performance of the proposed methods in Section IV, which is followed by conclusions in Section V.

Notations: The notations that are used throughout this paper are standard. n ×m denotes the set of n × m matrices. A real symmetric matrix P > 0(≥ 0) denotes P being positive definite (positive semidefinite). Sym{A} is the shorthand notation for A + A T . I n and 0 m ×n are used to denote the n × n identity matrix and m × n zero matrix, respectively. The subscripts n and m × n are omitted when the size is not relevant or can be determined from the context. For a matrix A ∈ m ×n with rank(A) = r < n, A ⊥ ∈ n ×(n -r ) denotes a matrix such that AA ⊥ = 0, and
div.formula: A T ⊥ A ⊥ > 0. diag{• • •} denotes a block- diagonal matrix.
div.p: The notation is used to indicate the terms that can be induced by symmetry.

div.head: II. MODEL DESCRIPTION AND PROBLEM FORMULATION
A. Continuous-Time Uncertain Takagi-Sugeno Fuzzy Affine Dynamic Model
div.p: It is known that many physical plants are very complex in practice; therefore, rigorous mathematical models would be very difficult, if not impossible, to obtain. Nevertheless, many of these systems can be expressed in some form of mathematical model locally or as an aggregation of a set of mathematical models [1], [5]. Here, we consider using the following T-S fuzzy affine dynamic model to represent a complex multiinput multioutput (MIMO) system which includes both local analytic linear models and fuzzy membership functions.
div.formula: Plant Rule R l : IF f 1 (x(t)) is F l 1 and f 2 (x(t)) is F l 2 and • • • and f ϕ (x(t)) is F l ϕ , THEN ⎧ ⎪ ⎨ ⎪ ⎩ ẋ(t) = (A l + ΔA l ) x(t) + a l + Δa l + Bu(t) + D l w(t) z(t) = L l x(t) + N l w(t) y(t) = C l x(t) + M l w(t), l ∈ {1, 2, . . . , r}
div.p: (1) where R l denotes the lth fuzzy inference rule; r is the number of inference rules; F l φ (φ = 1, 2, . . . , ϕ) are the fuzzy sets; x(t) ∈ n x is the system state; u(t) ∈ n u is the control input with matrix B being of full column rank; y(t) ∈ n y is the system measurement output; z(t) ∈ n z is the controlled output; w(t) ∈ n w is the disturbance input which is assumed to belong to L 2 [0, ∞); F(x(t)) := [f 1 (x(t)), f 2 (x(t)), . . . , f ϕ (x(t))] are the premise variables, which are not necessarily measurable; (A l , a l , B, D l , C l , M l , L l , N l ) denotes the lth local model of the system, and (ΔA l , Δa l ) denotes the uncertainty terms of the lth local model with the following form:

div.p: Remark 2.2: It is noted that the system models given in (1) or (5) are in fact affine systems instead of linear systems. They include an additional offset term a(μ) + Δa(μ). It has been shown that these models have much improved approximation capabilities [5], [40].

In this paper, we address the output feedback control problem of the fuzzy affine dynamic system in (5) which is based on a piecewise affine controller and a PQLF. Since the rules of the fuzzy system (1) induce a polyhedral partition of the state space, the global fuzzy system (5) can be viewed as a number of subsystems in a set of individual regions. Denote the state-space partition as {S i } i∈I and I as the set of region indices. In this paper, we follow the idea of [16] and [18] to divide the state space into two kinds of regions: crisp (operating) regions and fuzzy (interpolation) regions. The crisp region is defined as the region where μ l [x(t)] = 1 for some l, and all other membership functions evaluate to zero. The system dynamic of the crisp region is given by the lth local model of the fuzzy system (1). On the other hand, the fuzzy region is defined as the region where 0 < μ l [x(t)] < 1, and the system dynamic is given by a convex combination of several local models. Then, we can rewrite the global system (5) to be an equivalent piecewise fuzzy affine system as
div.formula: ⎧ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎨ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎩ x(t + 1) = (A i + ΔA i ) x(t) + a i + Δa i + Bu(t) + D i w(t) z(t) = L i x(t) + N i w(t) y(t) = C i x(t) + M i w(t), x(t) ∈ S i , i ∈ I (7)

div.p: For each local region S i , the set I(i) contains the indices for the system matrices that are used in the interpolation within that region. For a crisp region, I(i) contains a single element.

Let the partitioned regions be separated into two classes I = I 0 ∪ I 1 , where I 0 denotes the index set of regions that contain the origin, and I 1 denotes the index set of regions that do not contain the origin. It is, thus, known that a i + Δa i = 0 for all i ∈ I 0 .

div.head: B. Measurements Quantization
div.p: Because of the existence of the communication links between the physical plant and the controller, in this paper we consider the controller synthesis using quantized measurements, that is
where the function Q[•] represents a logarithmic static and timeinvariant quantizer, which is assumed to be symmetric, i.e.,

For each output channel, the set of the logarithmic quantization levels is described by [27], [28] (10) where ρ j ∈ (0, 1) denotes the quantization density. A small ρ j corresponds to a coarse quantizer, while a large ρ j means a dense quantizer. Each of the quantization level v ij corresponds to a segment of the measured output y j (t) such that the quantizer maps the whole segment of the measured output y j (t) to this quantization level. In addition, these segments form a partition of , i.e., they are disjoint, and their union equals to . For the logarithmic quantizer, the associated quantizer Q[•] is defined as follows, with δ j = 1-ρ j 1+ρ j :

div.head: C. Continuous-Time Piecewise Fuzzy Affine Observer Model
div.p: Given the uncertain T-S fuzzy affine dynamic system (7) in each region, we consider the following piecewise fuzzy affine dynamic observer.
Region Rule s: where x(t) ∈ n x is the estimated state; R s ∈ n x ×n y , s ∈ I , are the observer gains to be determined for each local region.
div.formula: IF x(t) ∈ S s , THEN Local Observer Rule R n : IF f 1 (x(t)) is F n 1 and • • • and f ϕ (x(t)) is F n ϕ , THEN ẋ(t) = A n x(t) + a n + Bu(t) + R s (Q [y(t)] -ŷ(t)) ŷ(t) = C n x(t), n ∈ I(s), s ∈ I (14)
div.p: Similarly, the overall piecewise fuzzy observer is inferred as follows:

div.p: ) Remark 2.3: It is noted that the premise variables of fuzzy affine systems in (1) are not fully measurable, which happens typically in the situations when general T-S fuzzy dynamic models are used to represent complex nonlinear systems via offline modeling [2], [5], [8], [13]. In such circumstances, the continuous-time fuzzy affine system in ( 7) is partitioned which is based on the general state space but not the measurable output space, and thus, there is no guarantee that plant (7) and the controller with observer ( 15)-( 17) always operate in the same region at the same time, especially in the initial period of the system dynamics. In this case, the approaches given in [11], [12], [14], and [20] cannot be applied. The main motivation for the investigation of nonsynchronized controller synthesis is that the premise variables of T-S fuzzy dynamic systems are not necessarily measurable. Nevertheless, it is also noted that in the network-based control framework, even when the premise variables of the T-S fuzzy dynamic systems in (1) are precisely known (measurable), it is usually difficult to retrieve these premise variables' information for the observer design in (14) due to the network-induced limitations such as signal quantization, packet dropouts, time delays, etc. In other words, in this case, the premise variables of the fuzzy observer are more often determined by the estimated states.

div.head: D. Observer-Based Output Feedback H ∞ Control Problem Formulation
div.p: Given the continuous-time T-S fuzzy affine dynamic system in (7), the objective of this paper is to design an admissible output feedback controller in form ( 14)-( 17) with a guaranteed performance in the H ∞ sense, that is, given a prescribed level of disturbance attenuation γ > 0, find a controller with ( 14)- (17) such that the closed-loop system (18) is globally stable and the induced L 2 -norm of the operator from w(t) to the regulated output z(t) is less than γ under zero initial conditions
div.formula: ∞ 0 z T (t)z(t)dt < γ 2 ∞ 0 w T (t)w(t)dt for all nonzero w(t) ∈ L 2 [0, ∞).

div.head: III. OBSERVER-BASED H ∞ OUTPUT FEEDBACK CONTROLLER ANALYSIS AND SYNTHESIS
div.p: In this section, we will present a number of results on nonsynchronized observer-based output feedback controller de-sign based on a common and a PQLF, respectively, for the continuous-time T-S fuzzy affine dynamic systems that are introduced in the previous section.

div.head: A. Output Feedback Control Based on a Common Quadratic Lyapunov Function

Remark 3.2: It is noted that the results that are obtained in Theorem 3.1 are based on CQLFs, which tend to be conservative, especially for complex highly nonlinear systems. It is also easy to see that in Theorem 3.1, to obtain the linear matrix inequality (LMI)-based conditions, a structural constraint is imposed on the common Lyapunov matrix P as in (71). Thus, more advanced design techniques that are based on piecewise Lyapunov functions are desirable.

div.head: B. Output Feedback Control Based on a Piecewise Quadratic Lyapunov Function

The procedure is directly based on the information in the fuzzy rule base. See [16] and [41] for details. Now, we are ready to present the following lemma. Lemma 3.1. Given a constant γ > 0, the closed-loop fuzzy control system in ( 18) is globally stable with disturbance attenuation level γ, if there exist a set of positive scalars ε is > 0, symmetric matrices T , W is , and U is , i, s ∈ I , such that W is and U is have nonnegative entries, and with

div.p: where It is noted that when the observer and controller gains are known, the conditions that are given in (39) and (40) are strict LMIs, and, thus, are useful to performance analysis for the closed-loop system in (18). Nevertheless, when the controller/observer gains are unknown, conditions (39) and ( 40) are bilinear matrix inequalities (BMIs), which are nonconvex, NP-hard, and, therefore, expensive to solve globally from a computational viewpoint [17], [42], [43]. Thus, the main purpose, hereafter, is to convexify the products of the systems matrices with the Lyapunov matrices. Nevertheless, it is noted that the continuity matrices F is in the Lyapunov matrix P is are generally not square. In addition, it is also noticed that indices of the Lyapunov matrices and the controller/observer gains are (i, s) and s, respectively, which are not the same. Thus, it is anticipated that conditions in (39) and (40) are not convenient when used for the controller/observer synthesis purpose. To resolve this difficulty, it shall be useful to eliminate the products between the system matrices and the Lyapunov matrices. Unfortunately, it is noted that in this continuous-time case the well-known inequality [21], [34] -G T P -1 G ≤ P -G -G T with P > 0 cannot be used to separate the Lyapunov matrices from the system matrices. Instead, the powerful Projection lemma (see Appendix A) will be exploited to realize the decoupling feature. The corresponding controller synthesis results are summarized in the following theorem.

Remark 3.5: By Projection Lemma and introducing two sets of slack variables G is , V is , it is easy to see that in (42), the Lyapunov matrices are not involved in the products with the system matrices. It is shown that this decoupling feature enables one to use the PQLFs and LMIs for the observer/controller syn-thesis purpose. Here, it is also worth mentioning that Theorem 3.2 is generally less conservative than Theorem 3.1, because a PQLF is adopted and no constraint is imposed on the piecewise Lyapunov matrices P is in (42). Nevertheless, it is also worth pointing out that when deriving the LMIs-based conditions in Theorem 3.2, we still impose up-triangular structural constraints on the slack variables as in (84), which inevitably brings some degree of design conservatism. To circumvent this drawback, two natural questions arise: Is it possible to separate the Lyapunov matrices in (77) from the system matrices, but without introducing any slack variables? If yes, are the resulting conditions more efficient for the synthesis purpose than the original BMIs-based ones given in Lemma 3.1? Fortunately, the answers are positive. div.p: (53) Now, we are in a position to present the following theorem. Theorem 3.3: Given a constant γ > 0, the closed-loop fuzzy control system in ( 18) is globally stable with disturbance attenuation level γ, if there exist sets of matrices Ks ∈ n u ×n x , ks ∈ n u ×1 , Rs ∈ n x ×n y , s ∈ I , a set of positive scalars ε is > 0, δ > 0, a set of symmetric matrices W is with nonnegative entries, i.e., W is 0, i, s ∈ I , and a symmetric matrix T with P is shown in (50) such that conditions (51) and (52) hold.

It is noted that the conditions given in (51) and (52) are still not convex due to the matrix equality constraint in (52). Several approaches have been proposed to solve such nonconvex feasibility problems, among which the cone complementarity linearization (CCL) method [45] is the most commonly used one; see, for example, [29], [32], [34], and [45]. The basic idea in the CCL algorithm is that if the LMI P I I X ≥ 0 is feasible with the n × n matrix variables P > 0 and X > 0, then Trace(PX ) ≥ n, and Trace(PX ) = n if and only if PX = I. Now, using a CCL method, the nonconvex feasibility problem that is given in Theorem 3.3 is converted to the following nonlinear minimization problem involving LMI conditions: 51), and
div.formula: Minimize Trace ⎛ ⎝ i,s∈I P is X is ⎞ ⎠ subject to (
P is > 0, X is > 0, P is I I X is > 0, i, s ∈ I . (54)
div.p: Then, the suboptimal performance of γ can be found by the following algorithm. The convergence of this algorithm is guaranteed in terms of similar results in [45].
Algorithm 3.1: Suboptimal performance of γ.
Step 1. Choose a sufficiently large initial γ > 0, such that there exists a feasible solution to (51) and (54). Set γ 0 = γ.
Step 2. Find a feasible solution ( Ks0 , ks0 , Rs0 , W is0 , X is0 , T0 , ε is0 ) satisfying conditions in (51) and (54). Set σ = 0.
Step 3. Solving the following LMI problem for the variables Ks , ks , Rs , W is , X is , T , and ε is : 51) and (54).

div.formula: W is(σ +1) = W is , X is(σ +1) = X is , T(σ+1) = T , and ε is(σ +1) = ε is .
div.p: Step 4. Substituting the gains [ K s k s R s ] = δ -1 [ Ks ks Rs ] that are obtained in Step 3 into the analysis conditions ( 39) and ( 40) in Lemma 3.1, and if the LMIs ( 39) and ( 40) are feasible with respect to the variables W is 0, U is 0, and P is satisfying (39), then set γ 0 = γ and return to Step 2 after decreasing γ to some extent. If (39) and (40) are infeasible within the maximum number of iterations allowed, then exit. Otherwise, set γ = γ + 1, and go to Step 3.

It is noted that although it is still not possible to always find the global optimal solution, the proposed nonlinear minimization problem is easier to solve than the original nonconvex BMIsbased feasibility problem in Lemma 3.1.

div.head: C. Discussions
div.p: Remark 3.6: It is noted that when deriving the relaxed condition in (81), we impose a structural constraint on the multiplier X in (80), that is, we set
div.formula: X = 0 G T is V T is T . (55)
div.p: Nevertheless, it is interesting to show that even with structural constraint, the relaxed condition (81) is still a necessary and sufficient condition for the original inequality in (77). We summarize this result in the following proposition. Proposition 3.1: There exists a solution P is , i, s ∈ I to (77) if and only if there exists a solution P is , G is , V is , i, s ∈ I to (81).
Proof. Necessity: By setting G is = P is and V is = I with → 0, (81) follows from (77).
Sufficiency: Define a nonsingular matrix z := ⎡

div.p: which implies that (77) holds. The proof is, thus, completed.

Remark 3.7: Note that the conditions given in Theorem 3.2 involve two tuning parameters: λ 1 and λ 2 . When these two scalar parameters are given, the conditions in Theorem 3.2 are strict linear matrix inequalities and can be solved by using the LMI toolbox [42], [46]. The problem is then how to find some combination of these scalars such that the LMIs have a feasible solution. A simple way to address the tuning issue is by the trial-and-error method. Another possible way is to apply some numerical optimization search algorithms (such as genetic algorithm or the program fminsearch in the optimization toolbox of MATLAB). It has been demonstrated that these optimization search procedures are indeed efficient for the LMIs-based parameter tuning problems [33], [44].

Remark 3.8: It is noted that all the conditions in Theorems 3.1 and 3.2 and Algorithm 3.1 are formulated in terms of linear matrix inequalities that can be solved by the polynomial time algorithms [46] with complexity proportional to σ 3 ρ, where σ and ρ are the number of scalar variables and number of rows in the LMIs, respectively. Especially, it is noticed that in Theorems 3.1 and 3.2 and Algorithm 3.1, the controller gains and the observer gains can be obtained simultaneously. It is also noted that the results that are given in this paper are obtained based on the assumption that the input matrix B is a common one. When the input matrix is not a common one, i.e., B l = B, l ∈ {1, 2, . . . , r}, the closed-loop matrices Ãmns and ã m ns in (67) can be expressed as
div.formula: Ãmns := A m + B m K s A m -A n + (B m -B n )K s -R s (C m -C n ) -B m K s A n -(B m -B n )K s -R s C n ã m ns := a m + B m k s a m -a n + (B m -B n )k s .
div.p: It is noted that for this case, with the presence of terms (B m -B n )K s and (B m -B n )k s , unfortunately, the convexification procedures that are presented in Theorems 3.1 and 3.2 are not applicable to the observer-based nonsynchronized output feedback controller design (see the last few steps in the proofs of Theorems 3.1 and 3.2). In this case, the well-known two-step design method [20] or BMIs-based approaches [17], [42], [43] can be applied for the corresponding controller synthesis. It is also noted that the crossing terms (B m -B n )K s and (B m -B n )k s emerge due to the nonsynchronized controller design. In other words, the convexification technique that is presented in Theorem 3.2 is applicable for the synchronized control case when the input matrix is not a common one; as for this case, these crossing terms are not involved. Finally, it is also worth pointing out that the design techniques that are presented in Theorem 3.3 (see Algorithm 3.1) are applicable to both the synchronized and nonsynchronized control cases when the input matrix is not a common one. Remark 3.9: It is noted that in practical NCSs, in addition to quantization effects, the network-induced signal transmission delay and data packet dropout are more or less existing at the same time, which can also degrade the performance of the systems and even cause system instability. In this paper, we have only considered the measurement quantization, but the study of nonsynchronized output feedback control of continuous-time networked nonlinear systems via T-S fuzzy affine models with simultaneous consideration of different types of network-induced constraints deserves further investigation.

div.head: IV. SIMULATION EXAMPLES
div.p: To illustrate the proposed controller synthesis methods, two simulation examples will be considered in this section.
Example 4.1. Consider the following T-S fuzzy affine dynamic system of form (1) with three local models. The system parameters are given by
The normalized membership functions are shown in Fig. 2. With the space partition used in this paper, we have the following three regions

, where d 1 and d 2 are selected to be d 1 = 50, d 2 = 2 × 10 3 , respectively. Here, the three regions can be represented by the following degenerate ellipsoids: For the piecewise Lyapunov functions-based approaches, the characterizing matrices Es and F s can be obtained as follows
From the regions shown in Fig. 2, we have I = {1, 2, 3}, I(1) = {1, 2}, I(2) = {1}, I(3) = {1, 3}. It is easy to see that S 2 is a crisp region and S 1 , and S 3 are fuzzy regions.

It is assumed that the premise variable x 1 (t) is not measurable. The objective is to design an observer-based piecewise fuzzy affine controller in the form of ( 14) and (17) such that the corresponding closed-loop system in ( 18) is asymptotically stable with H ∞ performance γ under measurement quantization. Assume that the quantization density ρ = 0.9 for the quantizer; it is noted that the approaches that are proposed in [8], [10]- [12], [14] and [20] are not applicable to the controller design for this fuzzy affine system. It has also been found that there is no feasible solution which is based on the common Lyapunov functions-based approach as given in Theorem 3.1. Nevertheless, by the piecewise Lyapunov functions-based approaches (see Theorem 3.2 and Algorithm 3.1), one indeed obtains feasible solutions. More specifically, by Theorem 3.2 with searched scalars λ 1 = λ 2 = 0.2, one obtains a feasible solution with H ∞ performance γ min = 5.3383, and the observer and controller gains are given by ⎡ This example clearly illustrates the advantages of piecewise Lyapunov functions-based synthesis methods over the common Lyapunov functions-based methods. In the next example, we consider an autonomous land vehicle system whose mission is to follow a given path [43].

Example 4.2. As shown in Fig. 3(a), the goal of this example is to design a controller that forces a cart on the xy plane to follow the straight line y = 0 with a constant velocity v 0 = 1 m/s. Here, it is assumed that a controller has already been designed to maintain a constant forward velocity. The cart's path is then controlled by the torque u about the z-axis according to the following motion equations:

where θ is the heading angle with time derivative ψ; I = 1(kg • m 2 ) is the moment of inertia of the cart with respect to the center of mass; k = 0.01 is the damping coefficient; u is the control torque; and w is the disturbance. It is assumed that the trajectories can start from any possible initial angle in the range θ ∈ -3π 5 , 3π 5 and any initial distance from the line. Define the states of the system as x = [ x 1 x 2 x 3 ] T := [ θ ψ y ] T and assume that the measured output and regulated output are given, respectively, by

Note that the orientation of the vehicle as measured by the heading angle θ introduces the nonlinearity sin(θ). It has been shown in [2], [5], and [7] that the fuzzy dynamic models can be utilized to approximate any smooth nonlinear functions to any accuracy in any compact set. It is noted that the chosen number of fuzzy local models depends on the particular application. Nevertheless, it is also noted that the more local models imply better precision and more computation cost, which is a tradeoff choice in practice. In this example, we choose three local models, that is, we approximate the system by the following T-S fuzzy affine model.
div.formula: Plant Rule R l : IF x 1 (t) is F l , THEN ⎧ ⎪ ⎨ ⎪ ⎩ ẋ(t) = (A l + ΔA l )x(t) + a l + Δa l + Bu(t) + D l w(t) y(t) = C l x(t) + M l w(t) z(t) = L l x(t) + N l w(t), i = 1, 2, 3
div.p: where the membership functions are shown in Fig. 2 with d 1 = π 15 , d 2 = 3π 5 , and the system parameters are given by

The three regions that are shown in Fig. 2 can be represented by the ellipsoids given by (57) with d 1 = π 15 , d 2 = 3π 5 , n x = 3. For the piecewise Lyapunov functions-based approaches, the characterizing matrices Es and F s are given in (58) with χ = [ 1 0 0 ], d 1 = π 15 , d 2 = 3π 5 , n x = 3. Similar to Example 4.1, under the measurement quantization, the objective is to synthesize an observer-based piecewise affine output feedback controller in the form of ( 14) and ( 17) for the aforementioned system with a guaranteed H ∞ performance. Choosing the quantization density ρ = 0.8 for the quantizer and the disturbance attenuation performance γ = 3.5, it has been found that there is no feasible solution by Theorems 3.1 and 3.2 given in this paper. Nevertheless, by applying Algorithm 3.1, one indeed obtains a feasible solution after 29 iterations. The corresponding observer and controller gains are given as follows: ⎡ To show the effectiveness of the obtained results, simulations have been carried out with different initial conditions, and it is found that the designed controller achieves satisfactory performance. Fig. 3(b) shows the time responses of the closed-loop system under initial conditions x(0) = [ π 2 0 2.5 ], x(0) = [ 0 0 0 ], and w(t) ≡ 0. Fig. 3(c) shows the measurement and quantized measurement. Fig. 3(d) shows the response of the ratio
div.formula: T 0 z T (t)z (t)dt T 0 w T (t)w (t)dt
div.p: under w(t) = 5e -2t sin(0.5t) and zero initial conditions. It can be observed that the time response performances are satisfactory, and it can also be seen from Fig. 3(d) that the ratio is less than 1.2, which is smaller than the prescribed disturbance attenuation level γ = 3.5, showing the effectiveness of the controller design.

Two simulation examples given in this section also indicate that Algorithm 3.1 may produce better results than Theorems 3.1 and 3.2, although the computation cost involved in Algorithm 3.1 is generally more than that in Theorems 3.1 and 3.2.

div.head: V. CONCLUSION
div.p: In this paper, based on common/PQLFs combined with S-procedure and some matrix inequality convexifying techniques, some new results have been developed for observerbased robust H ∞ output feedback control for a class of continuous-time T-S fuzzy affine dynamic systems with unmeasurable premise variables using quantized measurements. All the solutions to the controller synthesis are given in terms of linear matrix inequalities. Simulation examples are presented to demonstrate the design procedure and the advantages of the proposed controller design approaches. Applying the theoretical results that are developed in this paper to some real-world complicated systems such as the 3-D overhead cranes [47], continuous stirred tank reactor [48], solar air-conditioning systems [49], solid oxide fuel cell power systems [50], and so on, will be part of our future research.
